016package tech.uom.seshat;
017
018import java.util.Objects;
019import javax.measure.Unit;
020import javax.measure.Quantity;
021import javax.measure.UnitConverter;
022import javax.measure.quantity.Time;
023import javax.measure.quantity.Angle;
024import javax.measure.quantity.Length;
025import javax.measure.format.ParserException;
026import tech.uom.seshat.resources.Errors;
027
028
029/**
030 * Provides static methods working on {@link Quantity} instances.
031 * Seshat implementation of quantities has the following characteristics:
032 *
033 * <ul>
034 *   <li>Values are stored with {@code double} precision.</li>
035 *   <li>All quantities implement the specific subtype (e.g. {@link Length} instead of {@code Quantity<Length>}).</li>
036 *   <li>Quantities are immutable, {@link Comparable} and {@link java.io.Serializable}.</li>
037 * </ul>
038 *
039 * @author  Martin Desruisseaux (Geomatys)
040 * @version 1.0
041 */
042public final class Quantities {
043    /**
044     * Do not allow instantiation of this class.
045     */
046    private Quantities() {
047    }
048
049    /**
050     * Creates a quantity for the given value and unit of measurement symbol.
051     * This is a convenience method that combines a call to {@link Units#valueOf(String)}
052     * with {@link #create(double, Unit)}.
053     *
054     * @param  value  the quantity magnitude.
055     * @param  unit   symbol of the unit of measurement associated to the given value.
056     * @return a quantity of the given type for the given value and unit of measurement.
057     * @throws ParserException if the given symbol can not be parsed.
058     */
059    public static Quantity<?> create(final double value, final String unit) {
060        return create(value, Units.valueOf(unit));
061    }
062
063    /**
064     * Creates a quantity for the given value and unit of measurement.
065     *
066     * @param  <Q>    the quantity type (e.g. {@link Length}, {@link Angle}, {@link Time}, <i>etc.</i>).
067     * @param  value  the quantity magnitude.
068     * @param  unit   the unit of measurement associated to the given value.
069     * @return a quantity of the given type for the given value and unit of measurement.
070     * @throws IllegalArgumentException if the given unit class is not a supported implementation.
071     */
072    public static <Q extends Quantity<Q>> Q create(final double value, final Unit<Q> unit) {
073        Objects.requireNonNull(unit);
074        final Unit<Q> system = unit.getSystemUnit();
075        if (system instanceof SystemUnit<?>) {
076            final UnitConverter c = unit.getConverterTo(system);
077            final ScalarFactory<Q> factory = ((SystemUnit<Q>) system).factory;
078            if (c.isLinear()) {
079                /*
080                 * We require arithmetic operations (A + B, A * 2, etc.) to be performed as if all values were
081                 * converted to system unit before calculation. This is mandatory for preserving arithmetic laws
082                 * like associativity, commutativity, etc.  But in the special case were the unit of measurement
083                 * if related to the system unit with only a scale factor (no offset), we get equivalent results
084                 * even if we skip the conversion to system unit.  Since the vast majority of units fall in this
085                 * category, it is worth to do this optimization.
086                 *
087                 * (Note: despite its name, above 'isLinear()' method actually has an 'isScale()' behavior).
088                 */
089                if (factory != null) {
090                    return factory.create(value, unit);
091                } else {
092                    return ScalarFallback.factory(value, unit, ((SystemUnit<Q>) system).quantity);
093                }
094            }
095            /*
096             * If the given unit of measurement is derived from the system unit by a more complex formula
097             * than a scale factor, then we need to perform arithmetic operations using the full path
098             * (convert all values to system unit before calculation).
099             */
100            if (factory != null) {
101                final Q quantity = factory.createDerived(value, unit, system, c);
102                if (quantity != null) {
103                    return quantity;
104                }
105            }
106            return DerivedScalar.Fallback.factory(value, unit, system, c, ((SystemUnit<Q>) system).quantity);
107        } else {
108            throw new IllegalArgumentException(Errors.format(Errors.Keys.UnsupportedImplementation_1, unit.getClass()));
109        }
110    }
111
112    /**
113     * Returns the given quantity as an instance of the specific {@code Quantity} subtype.
114     * For example this method can be used for converting a {@code Quantity<Length>} to a {@link Length}.
115     * If the given quantity already implements the specific interface, then it is returned as-is.
116     *
117     * @param  <Q>      the quantity type (e.g. {@link Length}, {@link Angle}, {@link Time}, <i>etc.</i>), or {@code null}.
118     * @param  quantity the quantity to convert to the specific subtype.
119     * @return the given quantity as a specific subtype (may be {@code quantity} itself), or {@code null} if the given quantity was null.
120     * @throws IllegalArgumentException if the unit class associated to the given quantity is not a supported implementation.
121     */
122    @SuppressWarnings("unchecked")
123    public static <Q extends Quantity<Q>> Q castOrCopy(final Quantity<Q> quantity) {
124        if (quantity != null) {
125            final Unit<Q> unit   = quantity.getUnit();
126            final Unit<Q> system = unit.getSystemUnit();
127            if (!(system instanceof SystemUnit<?>)) {
128                throw new IllegalArgumentException(Errors.format(Errors.Keys.UnsupportedImplementation_1, unit.getClass()));
129            }
130            final Class<Q> type = ((SystemUnit<Q>) system).quantity;
131            if (!type.isInstance(quantity)) {
132                final ScalarFactory<Q> factory = ((SystemUnit<Q>) system).factory;
133                final double value = AbstractConverter.doubleValue(quantity.getValue());
134                if (factory != null) {
135                    return factory.create(value, unit);
136                } else {
137                    return ScalarFallback.factory(value, unit, type);
138                }
139            }
140        }
141        return (Q) quantity;
142    }
143}
